title: R43958
content: Some health care-related statutes in current law include time-limited provisions that will expire without further congressional action. These provisions often involve temporary increases or decreases in funding or special protections, such as bonus payments for certain Medicare mental health services. Examples of funding protections include establishing a floor for Medicare funding provisions. The list covers provisions expiring before the end of the first session of the 114th Congress. Medicare payments are reviewed annually for updates, but not every change in payments is considered an expiring provision. Some Medicare payment provisions are not considered expiring, such as the physician fee schedule update and recent changes in payment policy included in the ACA. These provisions specify adjustments that may result in negative payment updates, allowing rates to be lower than the previous year. The report includes expiring health care-related provisions that would require congressional action to extend once the expiration date is reached. Demonstration projects and pilot programs are excluded, and provisions that expired or were repealed in 2013 are listed separately. The expiring provisions are organized by SSA or PHSA title and section. The report lists expiring health care-related provisions that would need congressional action to extend once the expiration date is reached. Provisions with expiration dates in 2013 that were not extended in subsequent legislation are included, such as the Family-to-Family Health Information Centers program established by DRA Section 6064. The program provides grants to family-staffed organizations for children with special health care needs. Funding appropriations were made for FY2007-FY2009, with extensions through FY2012. The Family-to-Family Health Information Centers program, funded through various legislative acts, had appropriations extended until FY2015. Additionally, PRWORA authorized $250 million for abstinence education grants, with funding extended through June 30, 2009. The Family-to-Family Health Information Centers program received funding extensions through various legislative acts until FY2015, with additional appropriations for competitive grants in FY2012 and FY2013. The program is administered by the Administration for Children and Families (ACF). The funding for abstinence education grants was extended through various legislative acts until September 30, 2015, with appropriations allocated for specific fiscal years. The Maternal, Infant, and Early Childhood Home Visiting Program was established by ACA Section 2951 to provide grants for evidence-based home visiting programs. The program received $1.5 billion in funding from FY2010 to FY2014, with 3% allocated for research and evaluation and 3% for grants to tribal entities. Administered by the Maternal and Child Health Bureau at HRSA and ACF, the program supports in-home visits by health or social service professionals with at-risk families. The Maternal, Infant, and Early Childhood Home Visiting Program received funding from FY2010 to FY2014, with specific allocations for research, tribal entities, and in-home visits. The program's funding expires on March 31, 2015. ACA Section 2953 established the Personal Responsibility Education Program (PREP) to educate adolescents about abstinence, contraception, and adulthood. The ACA also required grants for innovative youth pregnancy prevention strategies targeting high-risk populations. The ACA and PAMA allocated a total of $375 million for youth pregnancy prevention from FY2010 to FY2014, with $75 million for FY2015. The funding for the PREP program expires on September 30, 2015. ACA Section 2953 established the program, which is administered by ACF. Additionally, CHIPRA required the Secretary to identify pediatric quality measures by January 1, 2010, and submit reports to Congress every three years. The Pediatric Quality Measures Program (PQMP) was required to be established by January 1, 2011, to identify measure gaps, award grants, and revise core measures. States must report annually to the Secretary on child health quality measures, with information made publicly available. Between FY2009 and FY2013, the Secretary could award up to 10 grants to states for projects improving children's health quality. The Secretary established a program to improve children's health care quality and develop a model electronic health record. The Institute of Medicine was required to report on child health status measurement. Funding of $45 million was appropriated annually from FY2009 to FY2013. PAMA extended funding for FY2014. Funding for SSA Section 1139A expired in FY2013 and for Section 1139A(b) in FY2014. ACA required the Secretary to publish a report. The Secretary established a program to improve children's health care quality and develop a model electronic health record. ACA required the Secretary to publish a core set of Medicaid adult health quality measures by January 1, 2012. A standardized format for reporting information based on this core measurement set was to be developed by January 1, 2013. The Secretary is required to submit a report to Congress every three years starting from January 1, 2014, to improve the quality of care for adults under Medicaid. Within one year of releasing the core set, a Medicaid Quality Measurement Program (MQMP) must be established, with grants and contracts awarded for developing innovative evidence-based measures for Medicaid adults. The Secretary is required to publish recommended changes to the core set of adult health quality measures for Medicaid annually. States must submit reports on state-specific adult health quality measures, with the Secretary collecting, analyzing, and making this information publicly available. Funding of $60 million for FY2010 through FY2014 was appropriated, with $15 million designated for SSA Section 1139A(b) in FY2014. The appropriation for funding under SSA Section 1139B(e) and SSA Section 1139A(b) expired in FY2014. Limits on outpatient therapy services were established by BBA 97, updated by the Medicare Economic Index. Various acts suspended these limits for different years, with DRA requiring an exceptions process for medically necessary services in 2006. The exceptions process for medically necessary therapy services was extended through CY2012, with an annual threshold of $3,700 for physical therapy, speech language pathology, and occupational therapy services. This increased amount applied to services in physicians' offices and hospital outpatient departments. The therapy cap exceptions process was extended through December 31, 2013, and then further extended through March 31, 2015 by ATRA and PAMA respectively. The cap and threshold also applied to therapy services in hospital outpatient departments and Critical Access Hospitals. Medicare performed manual medical reviews for services exceeding a $3,700 threshold. The therapy cap exceptions process and associated mandated medical review expire on March 31, 2015. Various legislative acts extended increased base payments for ground ambulance services in low population density rural areas until January 1, 2014. The MIPPA, PAMA, MMA, MIPPA, ACA, MMEA, and TPTCCA acts extended Medicare ambulance payments in low population density areas until March 31, 2015, with additional rate increases for rural and urban ambulance services in various periods. The MIPPA, TPTCCA, and ATRA acts extended Medicare ambulance payment increases until January 1, 2014. GAO and MedPAC were required to provide reports on ambulance provider costs and Medicare margins. MedPAC recommended not extending ambulance add-on payments in June 2013. The MIPPA, TPTCCA, and ATRA acts extended Medicare ambulance payment increases until January 1, 2014. The Department of Health and Human Services is required to conduct studies on ambulance costs and consult with the industry. Reports with recommendations were due to Congress by specific dates, but have not been issued yet. Payment increases were extended until March 31, 2015. The MIPAA Medicare rural and urban add-on payments expire on March 31, 2015. The add-on payments for physicians reporting quality measures were extended and modified by various acts until March 31, 2015. The incentives included bonus payments of 1.5% for 2007, 2008, 2009, and 2010. The Physician Quality Reporting System (PQRS) incentive payments were extended through 2014, with penalties for non-reporting starting in 2015. Eligible professionals received bonuses for successful reporting in 2010, 2011, 2012, and 2013. Providers who do not report quality measures starting in 2015 will face payment penalties of 1.5% in 2015 and 2% in 2016 and beyond. Eligible professionals can receive a 0.5% incentive payment from 2011 to 2014 if they meet Maintenance of Certification Program (MOCP) requirements. A qualified clinical data registry participation can fulfill quality reporting requirements for PQRS from 2014 onwards. The Medicare PQRS incentive payments expired on December 31, 2014, with penalties for professionals who do not report quality measures. Various legislative acts extended the work geographic index floor through different years, with Alaska having a set index of 1.5 since January 1, 2009. The work geographic index floor for Medicare physician fee schedule has been extended multiple times through legislative acts, with the current 1.0 floor set to expire on March 31, 2015. The Medicare physician fee schedule geographic index floor is set to expire on March 31, 2015. Incentive payments through Medicare Part B for meaningful use of EHR technology were authorized by ARRA, but will not be provided after December 31, 2016. MMA created Special Needs Plans for Medicare Advantage beneficiaries. Special Needs Plans (SNPs) for Medicare Advantage beneficiaries can restrict enrollment to specific beneficiary subgroups, such as those dually eligible for Medicare and Medicaid, institutionalized individuals, and those with severe chronic conditions. The authority for SNPs to limit enrollment expired on various dates but has been extended multiple times, most recently through December 31, 2015. The PSRA extended the time SNPs can restrict enrollment to special needs individuals until December 31, 2015, and PAMA extended it to December 31, 2016. Enrollment in SNPs will no longer be limited to special needs individuals after December 31, 2016. BBA 97 reinstated the MDH classification for small rural hospitals treating a high proportion of Medicare patients from October 1, 1997, to October 1, 2001. BBRA 99 extended the MDH program to October 1, 2006, and DRA extended it through discharges before October 1, 2011. The MDH program's payment structure is based on hospital-specific costs, with adjustments made over the years through various legislative acts. The program was extended multiple times until March 31, 2015, and the special payment status expired for discharges starting April 1, 2015. Additionally, the ACA eased requirements for hospitals to qualify for low-volume adjustments for FY2011 and FY2012. The low-volume adjustment for Medicare payments was extended multiple times through legislative acts until March 31, 2015. Starting April 1, 2015, hospitals must meet original standards of more than 25 road miles and less than 800 discharges to qualify for the adjustment. Additionally, the ACA eased requirements for hospitals to qualify for low-volume adjustments for FY2011 and FY2012. The ACA and subsequent legislative acts provided funding for outreach and education programs for low-income Medicare beneficiaries through various organizations such as SHIPs, AAAs, ADRCs, and AoA. Funding amounts were extended and appropriated through FY2013 and March 31, 2014. The ACA and subsequent legislative acts provided funding for outreach and education programs for low-income Medicare beneficiaries through organizations like SHIPs, AAAs, ADRCs, and AoA. Funding amounts were extended and appropriated through FY2013 and March 31, 2014, with further extensions and appropriations through September 31, 2014, and March 31, 2015. Funding for low-income Medicare beneficiary outreach and education is available through March 31, 2015, with various legislative acts establishing and extending Medicare programs. The length of time a cost plan contract could continue for a cost plan in an area served by multiple plans was extended multiple times by legislative acts, with the latest extension being until January 1, 2014. The length of time a cost plan contract could continue for a cost plan in an area served by multiple plans was extended by legislative acts until January 1, 2016. The contracts for MA regional and local plans with minimum enrollment in areas served by multiple plans will not be renewed after 2016. Incentive payments for EHR technology were authorized for hospitals from FY2011 to FY2014. ACA required a pre-rulemaking process to select quality measures for Medicare. The ACA outlined six steps for selecting quality measures for Medicare, including gathering input from stakeholders, making measures available to the public, and periodically reviewing and maintaining quality measures. $20 million was transferred from Medicare Trust Funds for this purpose. The ACA required funding transfers for quality measure selection activities under SSA Section 1890A(a)-(d) until March 31, 2015. MIPPA mandated the Secretary to contract with a consensus-based entity for performance improvement and measurement duties. The ACA, MIPPA, ATRA, PSRA, and PAMA mandated funding transfers for quality measure selection activities and performance improvement duties. Funding was extended through FY2013 and modified by ATRA, while PSRA required transferred funding to remain available until expended. PAMA required specific funding transfers for FY2014 and the first six months of FY2015. The funding for the contract with the consensus-based entity (NQF) will expire on March 31, 2015. Various Acts provided increases in Medicare's Home Health Prospective Payment System (HH PPS) for services in rural areas, with the latest increase set to expire on December 31, 2015. The Medicaid Qualifying Individual (QI) program received funding through various Acts, with the latest extension authorized by ATRA (Section 621) expiring on December 31, 2013. Total funds allocated for the program varied between different periods, reaching $730 million for FY2012. The QI program received funding through various Acts, with the latest extension authorized by PAMA (Section 201) expiring on March 31, 2015. Total funds allocated for the program varied between different periods, reaching $1.035 billion through the second quarter of FY2015. States establish their own payment rates for Medicaid providers under Medicaid. The federal government requires Medicaid payment rates for certain primary care services to be the same as Medicare rates for CY2013 and CY2014. The government covers the entire cost of this increase for those two years. The requirement for states to provide Medicaid primary care payments at parity with Medicare and full federal financing expired on December 31, 2014. States must continue Medicaid benefits for low-income families through transitional medical assistance (TMA) for up to 12 months as mandated by the Family Support Act of 1988. TMA requirements have been funded by short-term extensions since 1996. The TMA program has been extended multiple times, with the most recent extension expiring on March 31, 2015. Additionally, CHIPRA introduced the "Express Lane" eligibility option for states until September 30, 2013. The "Express Lane" eligibility option for states, which allowed for streamlined determinations of eligibility for programs like Medicaid and CHIP, is set to expire after September 30, 2015. Additionally, IACTA permits individuals over 19 years old to exclude the first $2,000 received for participating in a clinical trial for rare diseases when determining eligibility. The "Express Lane" eligibility option for states, allowing streamlined determinations of eligibility for programs like Medicaid and CHIP, is set to expire after September 30, 2015. Section 3(e) repeals the amendments made by this act five years after the date of enactment (or October 5, 2015), affecting Medicaid income eligibility for individuals participating in clinical trials for rare diseases. The ACA and HCERA added an FMAP increase for certain "expansion states," providing a 2.2 percentage point rate increase during 2014 and 2015 to states meeting specific criteria. The ACA and HCERA added a 2.2 percentage point FMAP increase for certain "expansion states" in 2014 and 2015. Vermont is the only state confirmed to meet the criteria for the additional FMAP increase. The additional FMAP increase for certain expansion states expires on December 31, 2015. The Balancing Incentive Payments (BIP) Program incentivizes states to increase spending on home and community-based services for long-term care. States must spend less than 50% of total Medicaid medical assistance on non-institutionally based LTSS to be eligible for incentive payments. The ACA authorized CMS to provide incentive payments to states for increasing spending on home and community-based services for long-term care. Participating states can receive an FMAP rate increase, with a maximum of $3 billion in incentive payments from 2011 to 2015. The authority for these payments will expire after September 30, 2015. Additionally, ACA Section 5507(a) required the Secretary to establish a demonstration project to award funds for health profession opportunity grants to help low-income individuals obtain education and training in healthcare jobs. The Health Professions Opportunity Grants program, funded through FY2015, provided financial aid and supportive services for education and training in healthcare jobs. The program received appropriations totaling $425 million from FY2010 to FY2014, with an additional $85 million allocated for FY2015. Additionally, the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) received federal funding through FY2015, with set appropriation amounts as the annual ceiling on spending to states and territories. The Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) was established in 1997 under the Balanced Budget Act, with subsequent appropriations provided through various federal laws. Funding was allocated for FY2008 through FY2013, with annual amounts specified for each year. The ACA provided annual national appropriation amounts for FY2014 and FY2015, totaling $19.1 billion and $21.1 billion respectively. FY2015 includes semiannual appropriations from SSA and a one-time appropriation from CHIPRA. State CHIP allotment funds are provided annually for two years, determined by even and odd year formulas. State CHIP allotments are determined annually using formulas based on previous year spending and adjusted for health care inflation and child population growth. Allotments can increase or decrease depending on each state's CHIP expenditures in the previous year. BBA97 authorized allotments for FY1998 through FY2007. The BBA97 authorized CHIP allotments for FY1998 through FY2007, with additional funding provided by DRA to eliminate FY2006 shortfalls. The U.S. Troop Readiness, Veterans' Care, Katrina Recovery, and Iraq Accountability Appropriations Act of 2007 allocated funds to address remaining CHIP funding gaps. Continuing Resolutions authorized FY2008 CHIP allotments until specified termination dates, with MMSEA extending FY2008 allotments through March 31, 2009, and authorizing FY2009 allotments. CHIPRA authorized allotments for FY2009 through FY2013, and ACA extended authorization through FY2015. The authorization for CHIP allotments was extended through FY2015. If a state's allotment is insufficient, funding sources like Child Enrollment Contingency Fund payments, redistribution funds, and Medicaid funds are available. Child Enrollment Contingency Fund payments have been available for states with funding shortfalls and CHIP enrollment exceeding target levels from FY2009 to FY2015. Not all states with funding shortfalls are eligible for these payments. The Child Enrollment Contingency Fund provides payments to states with CHIP funding shortfalls, based on enrollment growth and per capita spending. CHIPRA established the fund, extended by ACA through FY2015. Payments are authorized until September 30, 2015. Some states use federal CHIP funding to cover Medicaid expenses, especially those that expanded Medicaid eligibility before CHIP in 1997. The Medicaid and CHIP matching rates are used to finance the cost for children in Medicaid above 133% FPL in 11 qualifying states. The qualifying state option is authorized until FY2015. The State Children's Health Insurance Program Allotments Extension Act allows qualifying states to use certain funds for Medicaid expenditures. Technical Corrections with Respect to the Definition of Qualifying State changed the income standard and applicable dates for the option. DRA continued authority for qualifying states to use available FY2001, FY2004, and FY2005 CHIP funds for certain Medicaid expenses. The Medicaid and CHIP matching rates are used to finance the cost for children in Medicaid above 133% FPL in 11 qualifying states until FY2015. Various acts and resolutions have allowed qualifying states to use specific CHIP funds for certain Medicaid expenditures, with provisions extending through different termination dates. Qualifying states' ability to use FY2009 allotments for Medicaid expenses was permitted through March 31, 2009, and CHIPRA allowed the use of CHIP funds for FY2009 through FY2013 for Medicaid expenditures. The qualifying state option allows states to use CHIP funds for certain Medicaid expenditures until September 30, 2015. CHIPRA authorized $100 million in outreach and enrollment grants for fiscal years 2009 through 2013, with funds allocated for a national enrollment campaign, outreach for Native American children, and outreach campaigns in rural areas and underserved populations. Grant funds also target proposals addressing cultural and linguistic barriers to enrollment. ACA appropriated $140 million for FY2009 through FY2015 for these purposes. The ACA appropriated $140 million for CHIP outreach and enrollment grants from FY2009 through FY2015. The authority for these grants will expire after September 30, 2015. Additionally, the ACA created the Community Health Center Fund (CHCF) to provide mandatory funding for federal health centers in medically underserved areas. The ACA appropriated funds for CHIP outreach and enrollment grants from FY2009 through FY2015. The Community Health Center Fund received funding for health center construction and renovation for FY2011 through FY2015. The BBA97 authorized diabetes-related programs within the PHSA, transferring funds from CHIP to support research and services for diabetes prevention and treatment. The BBA97 authorized diabetes-related programs within the PHSA, transferring funds from CHIP to support research and services for diabetes prevention and treatment. Funding for the two PHSA diabetes-related programs will expire after various extensions of annual appropriations from FY1998 through FY2015. Funding for the National Health Service Corps, authorized by the ACA, will expire on September 30, 2015. The ACA allocated $1.50 billion annually from FY2011 through FY2015 for the NHSC. Funding for the NHSC is appropriated through FY2015. The ACA allocated $230 million for Graduate Medical Education payments to teaching health centers from FY2011 to FY2015. Funding for these payments has been provided until September 30, 2015. The ACA also authorizes grants to states for health insurance exchanges, with an indefinite appropriation for these grants. The HHS Secretary determines total amount available to states for exchange grants. Exchange grants authority terminated after December 31, 2014, but states can still use funding for exchange design. ACA included maintenance of effort provisions for Medicaid programs until December 31, 2013, and for Medicaid-eligible children until September 30, 2019. Failure to comply results in loss of federal Medicaid funding. Failure to comply with the ACA MOE requirements results in the loss of federal Medicaid funding. The ACA adult MOE requirement expired on December 31, 2013. States receive annual DSH allotments for Medicaid payments to hospitals treating low-income patients. DSH funding is capped, and each state has a maximum amount they can claim. Hawaii and Tennessee have special arrangements for their DSH allotments. Hawaii received a Medicaid DSH allotment for FY2012 and subsequent years through the ACA, while Tennessee received an allotment for FY2012. For FY2012 and onwards, Tennessee had Medicaid DSH allotments extended through various legislative acts. However, as of FY2014, Tennessee is the only state without a Medicaid DSH allotment. CHIPRA established performance bonus payments for states that increase Medicaid enrollment among low-income children above a defined baseline from FY2009 through FY2013. 27 states received bonus payments totaling $1.1 billion over five years. Bonus payments were based on meeting enrollment and retention provisions and achieving state-specific targets. Payments were authorized through FY2013. The CHIP program initially allowed states to extend coverage to uninsured pregnant women, parents, and childless adults through waivers, but Congress limited this practice. The DRA and CHIPRA laws restricted coverage for childless adults and parents, with the authority for parent coverage waivers expiring in 2013. The ACA provided funding for school-based health centers. The ACA provided $200 million for the construction and renovation of school-based health centers from FY2010 to FY2013. However, no funding was allocated for FY2014 and FY2015.
